components.text:
EXPLORING
THE LAND OF
FIRE & PUFFINS
Iceland has natural wonders in spades, from otherworldly lava fields, glaciers and geothermal lagoons, to the world's greatest light show.

ALTHOUGH IT IS RICH in beauty and history, Iceland is best known for two things: the quirky singer Björk and Eyjafjallajökull, the sub-glacial volcano that erupted in 2010, causing hundreds of ash-related flight cancellations and jokes about its comically unpronounceable name. In recent years, the scarcely populated mid-Atlantic island has also become known to Game of Thrones superfans as the haunting place where scenes “beyond the Wall” are filmed.

But incomprehensible monikers and occasional international headlines aside, Iceland is a truly fascinating, wild, and otherworldly destination worth at least a week of exploration, easily accomplished as an extended layover when flying between the U.S. and Europe. Situated on the unsteady divide between the slowly drifting American and Eurasian tectonic plates, the former Viking stronghold has become a cosmopolitan country with a stylish capital city, Reykjavík, featuring friendly, English-speaking locals and an abundance of culture and dining. Still, there’s a penetrating feeling that nature will always prevail.

At some point, most people pick up the adage that Iceland is green, while neighboring Greenland is icy. However, Iceland is rather chilly much of the time. Temperatures average between 36 and 57 degrees Fahrenheit, and the weather is known to change in a split second, making quick-drying layers imperative. Additionally, there are only four to five hours of daylight during winter, while in the summer the sun sets for just a couple of hours per night.

As for its reputation as the land of fire and ice, that’s thanks to 30 active volcanoes (on an island about the size of Kentucky) alongside plenty of glaciers and icebergs. There are also tens of thousands of tiny horses: one petite, wild-maned Icelandic steed for every four people, to be exact.
FOR WATER OF THE FROZEN VARIETY IT’S WORTH THE LONG—AND EXCEEDINGLY PHOTOGENIC—DRIVE TO JÖKULSÁRLÓN.

Appropriately enough, riding is a popular activity for tourists. Reykjavík's Íslenski Hesturinn is a top source for tours on the small but famously strong breed that practice several unique gaits including “tölt,” which legend has it is so smooth you can ride holding a glass of Champagne without spilling a drop.

Other thrilling activities in the untamed landscape include caving in lava tunnels, dog-sledding, ice-fishing, hiking, snowmobiling, and—believe it or not—golfing. There are several challenging and visually spectacular courses.

There are major plusses to visiting in the wintertime, the magical Northern Lights being the most significant. Of Aurora Borealis, lauded writer and poet W.H. Auden wrote in Letters From Iceland, “It was holy ground still, with the most magical light of anywhere on earth.” The spectacular neon show is best viewed between 11 p.m. and 2 a.m., though clouds can easily thwart those plans. At the Ion Hotel, guests soak in a heated outdoor pool while waiting for the fantastic display to light the sky; likewise at the Secret Lagoon natural hot springs in the Golden Circle.

items.caption: Melting ice feeds the local waterways.
The largest Puffin colony on earth is on Iceland’s Westmann Isles.
Moving glaciers have cut many fjords into Iceland’s coastline.

components.text: IT DOESN’T REALLY TELL YOU WHAT YOU’RE LOOKING AT. THE MOMENT YOU START TO MOVE, THE MOUNTAIN STARTS TO MOVE.

Indeed, geothermal spas are a major draw. One of the country’s most popular natural attractions is the Blue Lagoon; it's touristy but a must-do nonetheless (book tickets in advance). There, milky blue pools are naturally 98-104 degrees Fahrenheit year-round and full of silica, algae and minerals. (Tip: Coat your hair in plenty of the provided conditioner before and after soaking, as the spring water is extremely dehydrating.)

Iceland’s most famous waterfall is Gullfoss, or Golden Falls, into which pagan idols were tossed upon the country's conversion to Christianity some 1,000 years ago. At 160 feet, Europe’s most powerful waterfall is Dettifoss. The 70-foot spouting Geysir, after which all the world’s geysers are named, is also awe-inspiring.

For water of the frozen variety it’s worth the long—and exceedingly photogenic—drive to Jökulsárlón for a lagoon full of frolicking seals among icebergs that broke off of glaciers and floated out to sea. If it’s marine creatures that excite, Húsavik is the place for whale- and dolphin-watching (best from mid-June through July). Additionally, millions of adorable orange-beaked puffins—one of the national symbols of Iceland—live on the nearby island of Lundey. 

A truly singular experience can be had at Thingvellir National Park’s Silfra fissure (a UNESCO World Heritage Site) where, wearing a suit that exposes only the face and hands, it’s possible to actually scuba dive and snorkel between tectonic plates.

items.caption: Iceland is the world’s youngest country, geologically speaking.
Volcanic activity creates interesting thermal pools.
Iceland is famous for its sturdy equines.

components.text:
Iceland’s skies may be grey, but its largest metropolis, Reykjavík, is anything but. Reykjavík is the northernmost capital city in the world. Buildings, homes, and roofs in the quaint port city are painted vibrant colors, and are often adorned with flowers in the windows.

The city is compact and extremely walkable. Stroll past Hallgrímskirkja, the country’s tallest and most dramatic church; catch a show in the impressive geometric steel-and-glass Harpa concert hall; and shop the design stores on Skólavörðustígur Street and Kolaportid Flea Market for everything from wool sweaters to fermented fish. Along the way, stop to admire the city's vibrant street-art scene, or refresh yourself in one of the many local coffeehouses.

Museums in Iceland are unique to say the least. Visit Eldfjallasafn for a vast collection of volcanic rocks from around the world and volcano-related art, including a fiery Andy Warhol lithograph depicting Mount Vesuvius. There’s also Húsavik Whale Museum, which holds massive suspended skeletons of various species. The capital has several exhibits focused on Vikings and their lore, plus the singular Icelandic Phallological Museum.
ICELAND IS ADVANCED WHEN IT COMES TO FARMING, HARNESSING GEOTHERMAL ENERGY TO GROW FRUITS AND VEGETABLES.
WHAT TO SEE ON YOUR NEXT VISIT:

• The Northern Lights—on crisp, clear winter nights, visitors get a spectacular once-in-a-lifetime display.
  • The Blue Lagoon, or another milky blue geothermal hot springs, of which there are many.
  • Vatnajökull National Park is the place to see fire and ice together, as hot streams move alongside a vast ice cap.
  • Whale-watching via boat in the summertime means orcas, humpbacks, minke whales and giant blue whales.
  • Geysir, the first geyser known to man, has been active for some 10,000 years.

This remote country is advanced when it comes to farming, harnessing one of its most abundant resources—geothermal energy—to grow fruits and vegetables in hot houses. Steam vents rise across the terrain. There is even a cafe beside a hot river that cooks food—bread, cakes, hard-boiled eggs—in the ground via natural heat.

In Reykjavík, KEX Hostel offers modern industrial accommodations with a hip gastropub, while excellent Danish cooking is found at Narfeyrarstofa. Two hours outside the city, Hotel Budir is a must-visit for its gorgeous glacier-side location and restaurant known for its dedication to the slow food movement and local ingredients.

The rumors are true: Icelandic cuisine does involve both horse meat and whale. But one also finds plentiful fresh seafood, lamb and hot dogs—one of the nation’s most popular foods! Additionally, there is a burgeoning craft beer scene, featuring local brews made with some of the purest Arctic water on earth.

It’s just further evidence of the way Iceland’s strange and beautiful environs creep into every aspect of the magical destination with adventure around every bend. As Stephen Markley wrote in Tales of Iceland, “The problem with driving around Iceland is that you’re basically confronted by a new soul-enriching, breath-taking, life-affirming natural sight every five goddamn minutes. It’s totally exhausting.” Yet clearly worthwhile.
For more on this story visit the Iceland Tourism Site.
